Line 24: Line 24:
==Biography==
==Biography==
[[Image:wb 7thgrade.jpg|thumb|left|Walter Breuning in seventh grade, second from left, top row with blue "x", October 1907]]
[[Image:wb 7thgrade.jpg|thumb|left|Walter Breuning in seventh grade, second from left, top row with blue "x", October 1907]]
â
Walter Breuning was born in [[Melrose, Minnesota]]. He was the son of John Breuning and Cora Morehouse Breuning, and had two brothers and two sisters.<ref>{{cite census | title = Twelfth Census of the United States | year = 1900 | location = Melrose, Stearns, Minnesota | roll = T623 792 | page = 16A | line = 33 | accessdate = July 25, 2009}}</ref> In 1901 when he was 5, his family moved to [[De Smet, South Dakota]], where he went to school for nine years until his family broke up in 1910. Breuning referred to this time as "the dark ages", as his family lived without electricity, water, or plumbing, describing it as "carry the water in, heat it on the stove. That's what you took your bath in. Wake up in the dark, go to bed in the dark. That's not very pleasant".<ref>[http://www.yahoo.com World's oldest man marks 114th birthday in US]</ref> Longevity runs in Breuning's family. His paternal and maternal grandparents lived into their 90s, and his siblings lived to ages 78, 85, 91 and 100. His parents lived similar lifespans of their cohorts.
+
Walter Breuning was born in [[Melrose, Minnesota]]. He was the son of John Breuning and Cora Morehouse Breuning, and had two brothers and two sisters.<ref>{{cite census | title = Twelfth Census of the United States | year = 1900 | location = Melrose, Stearns, Minnesota | roll = T623 792 | page = 16A | line = 33 | accessdate = July 25, 2009}}</ref> In 1901 when he was 5, his family moved to [[De Smet, South Dakota]], where he went to school for nine years until his family broke up in 1910. Breuning referred to this time as "the dark ages", as his family lived without electricity, water, or plumbing, describing it as "carry the water in, heat it on the stove. That's what you took your bath in. Wake up in the dark, go to bed in the dark. That's not very pleasant".<ref>[http://www.yahoo.com World's oldest man marks 114th birthday in US]</ref> Longevity runs in Breuning's family. His paternal and maternal grandparents lived into their 90s, and his siblings lived to ages 78, 85, 91 and 100. His parents had long lifespans as well.<ref>http://www.greatfallstribune.com/article/20100919/NEWS01/9190301</ref>
In 1910 aged 14, Breuning dropped out of school; he began scraping bakery pans for $2.50 weekly.<ref name="Great Falls Tribune">[http://www.greatfallstribune.com/multimedia/breuning2/main.html Great Falls Tribune tribute site]</ref> He joined the [[Great Northern Railway (U.S.)|Great Northern Railway]] in 1913, working for it for more than fifty years. During his early years, Breuning commented that he would have to hide from owner [[James J. Hill]], as Hill did not want any railroad employees under the age of 18 (Breuning was first hired at age 17).<ref>[http://www.bnsf.com/employees/communications/bnsf_today/2009/01/2009-01-08-b.html Railroad Retiree is Nation's Oldest Living Man, BNSF News, January 8, 2009]</ref> Breuning worked for the Great Northern Railway until age 66, and was also a manager/secretary for the local [[Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine|Shriner's]] club until age 99.<ref>http://www.greatfallstribune.com/multimedia/breuning2/page17.html</ref> During [[World War I]], he signed up for military service, but was never called up. He moved to Montana in 1918, where he continued working as a clerk for the Great Northern Railway. There, he met Agnes Twokey, a telegraph operator from [[Butte, Montana|Butte]]. He was married to her from 1922 until her death in 1957. They had no children and Breuning never married again stating that "Second marriages never work; even first marriages don't work today.â<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-9UPU2ThSDs&feature=related|title=Oldest Man's 113th Birthday|publisher=CBS|date=September 21, 2009|accessdate=April 13, 2010|last=Hartman|first=Steve}}</ref> When [[World War II]] broke out, he was too old to serve.
In 1910 aged 14, Breuning dropped out of school; he began scraping bakery pans for $2.50 weekly.<ref name="Great Falls Tribune">[http://www.greatfallstribune.com/multimedia/breuning2/main.html Great Falls Tribune tribute site]</ref> He joined the [[Great Northern Railway (U.S.)|Great Northern Railway]] in 1913, working for it for more than fifty years. During his early years, Breuning commented that he would have to hide from owner [[James J. Hill]], as Hill did not want any railroad employees under the age of 18 (Breuning was first hired at age 17).<ref>[http://www.bnsf.com/employees/communications/bnsf_today/2009/01/2009-01-08-b.html Railroad Retiree is Nation's Oldest Living Man, BNSF News, January 8, 2009]</ref> Breuning worked for the Great Northern Railway until age 66, and was also a manager/secretary for the local [[Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine|Shriner's]] club until age 99.<ref>http://www.greatfallstribune.com/multimedia/breuning2/page17.html</ref> During [[World War I]], he signed up for military service, but was never called up. He moved to Montana in 1918, where he continued working as a clerk for the Great Northern Railway. There, he met Agnes Twokey, a telegraph operator from [[Butte, Montana|Butte]]. He was married to her from 1922 until her death in 1957. They had no children and Breuning never married again stating that "Second marriages never work; even first marriages don't work today.â<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-9UPU2ThSDs&feature=related|title=Oldest Man's 113th Birthday|publisher=CBS|date=September 21, 2009|accessdate=April 13, 2010|last=Hartman|first=Steve}}</ref> When [[World War II]] broke out, he was too old to serve.
